awd_titl_txt: RII Track-4: Real-Time Radiation Dosimetry Using Flash Memory
awd_abstract_narration:
Throughout the world, radiation exposure has been on the rise due to the increased use of nuclear power, medical procedures, nuclear weapons and natural disasters affecting power plants such as in Fukushima, Japan. Increased exposure to radiation has both short- and long-term detrimental effects on the human body and rapid diagnosis (triage) of an absorbed dose of radiation is critical for survivability. Thus, it is critical to have a fast, cost-effective and field-deployable personal dosimetry solution without the overhead of additional hardware or processing equipment. The project will develop a handheld, real-time radiation dosimetry solution using commercially available flash memory chips. Since memory chips are widely used in many embedded systems (e.g., smartphones) and wearable devices (e.g., fitness belts), this project’s concept could provide a paradigm shift in radiation dosimetry through distributed smart devices, which will be very useful for health monitoring, remote sensing, military applications, nuclear-reactor safety and space applications. In addition, the project has a strong educational component that includes the training of underrepresented students, the involvement of undergraduate students in research and the incorporation of the project's research findings into coursework.

The objective of this project is to develop a novel cost-effective radiation-dosimeter technology using the bit error rate of commercial flash memory. The dosimetry solution will provide real-time read-out of absorbed dose value, which is ideal for rapid diagnosis applications to minimize health risk for those who work closer to radiation environment. The technology can also facilitate a wireless sensor network (e.g., through smartphones), and transmit data to a central facility to provide better situational awareness over a larger area. The project takes advantage of the instrumentation and expertise at Oak Ridge National Laboratory to demonstrate the validity of a flash memory-based dosimetry concept through a series of radiation-exposure experiments. Both modeling and experimentation will be performed to determine the range of operation of the proposed dosimeter and to enhance its accuracy, sensitivity and selectivity. In addition, we propose novel measurement techniques in order to understand and quantify the (i) dose-enhancement effect when ionizing radiation goes through the back end of the line metal layers of a chip, (ii) directionality effects of the incident radiation beam on the memory and (iii) ionization vs. displacement damage effect in the flash-memory array. Thus, this research advances our knowledge on the radiation-matter interaction and the radiation-related reliability physics of semiconductor devices. The research will also enable a wireless, passive, in-situ, real-time radiation-dosimetry solution that can be customized for a wide range of applications including personnel dosimetry, safety, space and commercial applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project commenced in 2019 with the objective of developing a handheld, real-time radiation dosimetry solution using commercial flash memory chips. Traditional dosimeter technologies, such as Thermoluminescent dosimeters (TLD), film badge dosimeters and Optically Stimulated Luminescence (OSL) dosimeters have limitations for autonomous in-field applications due to elaborate (off-line) read-out steps. A flash memory-based dosimetry solution offers advantages like passive, in-situ, real-time measurement, and compatibility with existing embedded electronic platforms. However, achieving desired accuracy, sensitivity, and selectivity presents a significant challenge, compounded by inherent process variations in commercial memory chips. To address these issues, the project takes a comprehensive approach, involving detailed chip characterization and rigorous radiation testing to optimize sensor capabilities.  

 

 Two graduate students received partial funding from this project. One student completed her Ph.D. and joined Micron Technology. The other student successfully defended his M.S. thesis. Throughout the project, the PI and graduate students made several visits to Sandia National Laboratories to conduct irradiation experiments. First, the necessary instrumentation and electronic platform for irradiation experiments on commercial-off-the-shelf (COTS) flash memory chips were built. Then multiple irradiation experiments were conducted on COTS memory chips using the Co-60 gamma-ray source at Sandia National Laboratories. Systematic evaluation of the bit error response of the flash memory chips, as a function of total dose using digital read-out, demonstrated radiation sensitivity of 100 rad (Si) with multi-level-cell (MLC) flash technology.

 

Next, analytical modeling of the bit error response as a function of the total absorbed dose was successfully conducted, offering crucial insights for dosimeter design. Additionally, potential sources of errors, including thermal noise, retention errors, radiation directionality, and chip-to-chip variation, were identified and solutions are proposed to mitigate these errors involving detailed pre-characterization of the memory chips. Multiple papers were published based on this study, exploring the suitability and sensitivity limits of flash-based dosimeters. The project results contributed to the completion of a Ph.D. thesis outlining fundamental design rules for flash-based dosimeters.

 

Towards the end of the project, investigation into techniques for enhancing sensitivity in the flash-based dosimeter was conducted. It was demonstrated that the sensitivity of the flash-based dosimeter can be improved to nearly 10 rad(Si) by employing triple-level-cell (TLC) flash technology. In addition to influencing graduate thesis work, the research outcomes have been incorporated into the curriculum of the Hardware Reliability course by the PI. The topic of radiation effects on microelectronics is actively covered in training sessions for both graduate and undergraduate students in the PI's laboratory. Furthermore, mentorship by the PI extends to guiding undergraduate students in senior design projects that utilize results from this project. Numerous publications in reputable journals and conferences have also been yielded by the project.
